;2023 年 9 月，Penguin Classics，一家著名的优雅亲英版本和便携式规范文本出版商 — Robert Fagles 翻译的 ;维吉尔的《埃涅阿斯纪》;、托马斯·哈代的“;市长卡斯特桥;”——发布了三本书，将“经典”一词推向新的、有争议的领域：“;X 战警;”、“;复仇者联盟;，”和“;神奇四侠;。”这些精美的精装书，其镀金边缘使它们看起来像莎士比亚的收藏版，大多以十九世纪六十年代的早期漫威故事为特色，即漫画爱好者有时称之为漫画的白银时代。他们加入企鹅卷“;黑豹，;” “;美国队长;”和“; 《超凡蜘蛛侠》;”，去年出版。那些认为经典是经过时间考验的巅峰之作、我们在学校读过的书籍或已故白人的作品的人可能会感到惊讶。 “只有当文明成熟时，经典才会出现，”一位死去的白人 TS 艾略特 (TS Eliot) 在 1944 年吟诵道。“它必须是成熟思想的作品。”企鹅出版社的第一部经典著作于 1946 年出版，是 EV Rieu 对 ;奥德赛;。钢铁侠和金刚狼是如何与奥德修斯和伊丽莎白·班纳特占据同一架子的？

;

;第一批“经典漫画”来自十九世纪四十年代，是经典小说，例如“;白鲸;”和“;艾芬豪;”重铸以漫画书的形式——久负盛名的知识产权，历史悠久，已经进入公共领域。那个时期的超级英雄漫画，后来被昵称为黄金时代，并没有标榜自己是经典的、文学的或经久不衰的：它们承诺的是刺激、悬疑和冒险，就在当下。第一批以漫威漫画为名的故事也是如此。 《超凡蜘蛛侠》第 1 期（1963 年 3 月）的封面承诺“两部精彩的长篇蜘蛛侠惊悚片！”它的醒目页面让该系列听起来像是与经典相反：“从来没有像蜘蛛侠这样的英雄！”

;

;不过很快，作家斯坦·李以及艺术家杰克·柯比和史蒂夫·迪特科开始即兴发挥著名文学的语言。 《复仇者联盟》第 1 期（1963 年 9 月）将其与洛基的对决称为“众星云集的长篇超级史诗系列的第一部，其中包括地球上最伟大的超级英雄！”你几乎会认为他们在写奥德修斯或贝奥武夫。 （事实上​​，他们写的都是关于托尔的故事，这位北欧传说中时而头脑迟钝的风暴之神，至今仍是漫威的一个主要角色。）“史诗”曾经是一个特定的文学评论术语，后来变成了任何超级英雄的漫画术语。跨越多个问题的故事。

;

;白银时代史诗也可能会呼应像 ;《伊利亚特》;。他们的插图任务将整个文化的价值观与值得尊敬、善意的对手进行斗争：正如荷马的赫克托王子努力保护特洛伊免受希腊人的掠夺一样，漫威的对手纳摩王子，潜艇水手，想要保卫他的亚特兰蒂斯王国免受人类的侵害入侵。 《伊利亚特》也介绍了继续进行进一步冒险的英雄队伍。其衍生作品包括维吉尔的《埃涅阿斯纪》和乔叟的“;特洛伊罗斯和 Criseyde;。”漫威的《复仇者联盟》本身就是一个衍生剧，是将钢铁侠、雷神托尔、绿巨人浩克等人聚集在一起的一种方式。它建立了他们共同的准神话世界，这使得漫威能够向喜爱现有英雄的读者推销新英雄。

;

;漫威粉丝不仅成为蜘蛛侠和雷神的粉丝，还成为漫威本身的粉丝。他们在漫画中、在一些元叙事中看到了创作者，这些元叙事的出现早于复活节彩蛋和斯坦·李在漫威电影中的客串。 “在这本史诗般的期刊中，惊喜接踵而至，”《神奇四侠》第 10 期的封面承诺，“因为你实际上在故事中遇到了李和卡比！！！”成人和青少年粉丝给编辑写了一些内容丰富的信件，这些信件被印在他们喜欢的漫画中。 “我们都 22 岁，我丈夫是大学毕业生，”《复仇者联盟》第 26 期的一位记者夸口道。他们可以加入 Merry Marvel Marching Society，这是一个授权粉丝俱乐部，拥有“TTB（泰坦尼克号忠实信徒）”和“KOF（火焰守护者）”等头衔。他们再次通过信件页面争夺漫威无奖奖，这是一份毫无价值的证书，颁发给那些解释了不一致、艺术家错误或编辑失误的粉丝。漫画正在成为不同意义上的经典：不是古老的，不一定是教育性的，而是冒险故事，为进一步的冒险奠定了基础，围绕这些故事可以形成强大的社区。;

;在他有影响力的书中“ ;想象的社区;，”本尼迪克特·安德森认为，共享阅读——报纸、小册子、小说——使现代欧洲国家成为可能。法国人用法语分享新闻和故事；英国人通过《伦敦新闻画报》、狄更斯的书和莎士比亚的崇拜走到了一起。当杰克·柯比 (Jack Kirby) 于 1970 年离开漫威，而李则于 1972 年辞去主编职务时，他们和他们的同事已经建立了一个微型国家：追随者精通秘密身份、地理和历史的语言。 ，渴望只有他们才能理解的新闻，并准备打造下一代。罗伊·托马斯 (Roy Thomas) 于 1966 年接手了《X 战警》和《复仇者联盟》，成为众多漫威粉丝中第一个转为职业选手的人，他们从小就阅读超级英雄漫画，然后受雇于学者们倾向于认为，白银时代漫画的持久力不是因为它们是永恒的，而是因为它们属于他们的时代。超人和蝙蝠侠等黄金时代的典范是具有传奇色彩的榜样，而白银时代的英雄则面临着普通人的问题。蜘蛛侠饰演的彼得·帕克总是需要钱，却很少得到女孩。 “为什么事情似乎总是不适合我？”他脱下戏服，沉思起来。 “为什么我好像会伤害别人？” X战警最初的青少年名单包括一个班级小丑（冰人）、一个自作聪明的人（杂技野兽）和一个冷酷负责的队长（独眼巨人），他不敢约他梦中的女孩。神奇四侠像一个可爱且知名的家庭一样生活、工作和争吵。读者——尤其是但不仅限于年轻人——可以从这些人物中看到他们自己的麻烦。这些漫画反映了六十年代（《黑豹》除外，他在七十年代获得了他的第一部多期漫画）。他们专注于地下核试验、反抗中的时髦青年以及流行的弗洛伊德精神分析。 “你可能要花几个月的时间来对我进行心理分析！我抽不出时间来！”陷入困境的史蒂夫·罗杰斯（美国队长的另一个自我）抱怨道。

;
;
;

;不过，仅靠及时性并不足以保持所有这些漫画都还活着，更不用说将它们引入经典了。 ;X-Men; 的销量太少，以至于漫威在 1970 年停止发布新的冒险系列。（该系列直到七十年代末和八十年代初才变得流行，甚至成为标志性的，并由一个由作家克里斯·克莱蒙特（Chris Claremont）、艺术家戴夫·科克鲁姆（Dave Cockrum）和约翰·伯恩（John Byrne），以及作家和编辑路易丝·西蒙森（Louise Simonson）和安·诺森蒂（Ann Nocenti）。）美国队长甚至不是来自白银时代；而是来自白银时代。卡比和乔·西蒙在四十年代创造了他，他在六十年代的冒险经历强调了他作为最伟大一代的继承人的地位，一个过时的孤独人。这些书中收录的最强漫画，不仅捕捉了时代，而且指向了时代。

;

;故事在一代代读者的整理、谈论、模仿、推荐中成为经典。在这种情况下，婴儿潮一代在它们首次亮相时阅读它们，X一代随着它们的续集长大，千禧一代通过漫威电影遇到它们。每一代的粉丝——最初的粉丝，越来越多的粉丝，以及如今的非二元粉丝——不仅找到了阅读漫画的新方式，还找到了使用漫画的新方式。卡农就是这样形成的。几十年来，业余爱好者和专业人士在哪些书重要以及为什么重要方面达成了共识，否则他们喜欢争论这个问题，而我们就得遵循这些论点。当拥有出版、教学和编辑权力的一代人与前一代人出现分歧时，经典就会兴衰，获得作品，也会失去其他作品。

;
;
;

;对于现在的一代人来说主管文学出版，漫画可以成为经典。回想起来，我们可以看到为什么这些标题和这些具体问题（例如《神奇四侠》第 48-50 期，但不是第 43 期）很重要。 《蜘蛛侠》、《神奇四侠》和其他漫画的“经典”期代表了连载漫画中作为视觉艺术或故事转折点的高潮——而且往往两者兼而有之。对粉丝来说重要的故事可能比封面吹捧的故事具有更低、更不明显的风险。我们知道变形的斯库鲁人不会毁灭地球，否则就不会有下一个问题。但镭射眼会邀请漫威女孩出去吗？里德·理查兹会和他的女朋友苏·斯托姆结婚吗？直到我们阅读之后我们才知道。与其说这是冒险故事的逻辑，不如说是漫威也出版的浪漫漫画的逻辑。 （参见模特米莉。）道格拉斯·沃尔克（Douglas Wolk）阅读了 1961 年至 2017 年间出版的所有漫威漫画，为他的书《;所有Marvels;”（2021）解释说，漫威六十年代的标志性作品通过“将怪物漫画、浪漫漫画和幽默漫画吸收到超级英雄漫画中”而得以激增。冒险，但也有焦虑；打斗，还有讽刺和肥皂剧。

;黑豹进入这一经典的旅程后来开始，并走了一条不同的道路。企鹅出版社的版本于 1966 年开始，瓦坎达是一个“位于赤道非洲中心”的科技乌托邦，在《神奇四侠》漫画中首次出现。然后它跳到 1973 年至 1976 年间出版的 16 部漫画。所有漫画都是由唐·麦格雷戈 (Don McGregor) 编写的，他发展了后来的编剧和编剧将使用的神话故事——《基尔芒格》、《勇士瀑布》、《皇家宫殿》。 （“当我被从黑豹上取下来时，”麦格雷戈说，“有人告诉我这是因为我太接近黑人的经历了。我看着我的白手。”）麦格雷戈和铅笔师比利·格雷厄姆塑造了一个战士——在瓦坎达之外可以成为超级英雄的国王，但在家里却必须学会成为果断的统治者和浪漫的男主角。瓦坎达与漫威宇宙的其他部分存在一定距离——无论是概念上还是实际上都是另一个国家。它必须等上几十年，并得到好莱坞的推动，才能成为不仅仅是一种崇拜的经典。

;

;当散文作家在十八世纪的文学地位上升时，诗歌爱好者认为中等粗俗。这种态度可能需要数年时间才能改变，而漫画是一个特殊的出发点：它们不仅是一种文本媒介，而且是一种视觉媒介。柯比（Kirby）或他的《美国队长》继任者吉姆·斯特兰科（Jim Steranko）创作的一部顶级漫画几乎不需要言语。您只需观察角色的行为和反应即可了解故事情节。值得庆幸的是，企鹅出版社对这些图像进行了公正的处理。他们在厚厚的白纸上用明亮、平坦、彩色的墨水再现了六十年代的漫画——与旧新闻纸上使用的点式处理不同，但也许更真实地体现了他们大胆、追逐刺激的精神。

;

;; 《神奇四侠》年度第 6 期（1968 年），整页展示了一个橙黑相间的物体通过洋红色新星爆发向后坠落。 《火炬》讲述了他“无助地被抛入太空……”的故事。 。 。就像一群无力的布娃娃！”在前景中，里德·理查兹痛苦地尖叫；我们只能看到他的脸，其他部分都在画面之外。他像巴洛克画作中的伊卡洛斯一样倒下了。在整个卡比的故事中，尤其是在《神奇四侠》中，太空时代的英雄们横扫梦幻般的背景：星星、星云，甚至还有手绘人物叠加的黑白照片拼贴。卡比工艺的顶峰在墨水师乔·辛诺特和一位未注明出处的调色师（可能是玛丽·塞维林）的协助下，出现得稍早一些，在吞噬者的奇观中——一个巨大的、经常戴着紫色头盔、满嘴紫色散文的坏人。他是一名太空旅行者，也是一个奇观，对人类的苦难漠不关心。后来的漫画家还没有能与他相媲美。

;

;李、柯比和迪特科现在都已经死了。顾名思义，经典作品已经过时了，而且这些书籍的某些部分已经过时了。尽管有石头人的例子，但传统上丑陋或明显毁容的角色通常都是恶棍，从伤痕累累、复仇心切的九头蛇夫人到又大又圆、闷闷不乐的斑点。解决民权斗争的尝试因温和的中间主义而受到影响。恶棍们无缘无故地解释他们的计划；一切都带有感叹号。女性（或“女孩”，如隐形女孩）拥有女性的力量，例如收缩、间谍或隐形；很少有两个或两个以上的女性交谈。有些情节毫无意义。但这些漫画与那个时代的几乎所有其他流行文化产品以及我们自己的许多流行文化产品都有这样的缺陷。我们一直在阅读它们，寻找它们的突出之处。

;

;白银时代的漫威意味着情感（《X战警》中独眼巨人和漫威女孩的相思；《神奇四侠》中石头人的抑郁）和奇观：一个令人惊叹的世界具有新视角的眼睛、闪亮的星际小玩意和永远在行动的英雄。但在漫画中，这个世界在没有竞争的情况下能够为更多的读者做更多的事情。在现代数字图形之前，在《星球大战》之前，在电子游戏之前，只有在四色漫画的页面中，这样的宇宙事迹和超人壮举才能找到合适的视觉形式。六十年代电影的特效在今天看起来很俗气，但六十年代早期漫画的视觉效果在现代屏幕上却出奇地好。

;

;对于现代超级英雄漫画来说，这是一个问题。长期的漫威角色现在适合史诗电影，从“;X战警;”到“< a href="https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-comic-book-aesthetic-comes-of-age-in-across-the-spider-verse">;蜘蛛侠：跨越蜘蛛侠宇宙;”。就像今天正在被重新发明的其他经典故事一样，它们至少有时会出现在电视上（“女绿巨人”、“惊奇女士”），并且它们激发了文学小说的灵感，来自迈克尔·查邦（Michael Chabon）的普利策奖获奖作品《<数据提供》 -url="https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Adventures-Kavalier-bonus-content-ebook/dp/B0070O5F4U" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink"," outgoingURL”：“https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Adventures-Kavalier-bonus-content-ebook/dp/B0070O5F4U”}" href="https://www.amazon.com/Amazing-Adventures- Kavalier-bonus-content-ebook/dp/B0070O5F4U" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">;The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay;” (2000) 到鲍勃·普罗尔 (Bob Proehl) 的关于超能力变种人的被忽视且令人心碎的小说， “;无人之人;”和“;The Somebody People;”（2019-20）。简而言之，当今的超级英雄漫画存在竞争。尽管更广泛的媒体表现良好 - 请参阅 ;Alison Bechdel; 的切片生活图文回忆录或雷娜·特尔格迈尔 (Raina Telgemeier) 的儿童漫画——装订连续剧现在面临着身份危机。药店不再出售它们；只有专门的漫画店才有。 （您也可以付费在线阅读。） 1991 年出版的《X 战警》是有史以来最畅销的漫画书，其销售数字可能是无与伦比的。电子游戏或许能更好地满足我们的幻想； Netflix 更易于导航。

;超级英雄漫画仍然有关于不断发展的角色和他们共享的世界的持续故事。对于那些想要比好莱坞所能提供的更多故事或不同故事的粉丝来说，它们是一个社区所在地，并且它们为新艺术家、新作家和老团队中的新英雄提供了空间。因为它们的制作成本比电影或电视便宜得多，所以有时会让编剧承担更多的风险。在漫威电影或白银时代漫画中，你不会发现年轻、明确的跨性别者之间的友谊占据中心舞台，但你可以在漫威的;新变种人;（2020）的美丽而复杂的问题中看到这一点。 -23)，由维塔·阿亚拉 (Vita Ayala) 撰写，随后由查理·简·安德斯 (Charlie Jane Anders) 撰写。

;

;

;去年，根据 ;美国人口普查局的新报告;显示，美国儿童贫困增加了一倍多。这一急剧增长伴随着所有年龄段贫困率的普遍上升，在此之前贫困率连续两年下降，这在很大程度上归功于联邦政府在大流行期间提供的支持。就儿童贫困而言，2022年增长的最重要驱动因素是扩大的儿童税收抵免的到期，由于参议院共和党人和乔·曼钦的反对，拜登政府和国会民主党去年无法续签该税收抵免。

;

;为了谈论这份报告，我最近与哥伦比亚大学社会工作学院贫困与社会政策中心主任克里斯托弗·威默（Christopher Wimer）通了电话。在我们的谈话中，我们讨论了为什么儿童税收抵免在减少贫困方面如此成功，各州是否可以填补联邦政府留下的空白，以及应该从大流行时代吸取什么教训。扩大社会安全网。

;

;;这份报告告诉我们什么，它是如何得出关于过去一年儿童贫困率的结论的？;

;<它显示了很多人所期待的——即使用补充贫困衡量标准，这是比美国官方衡量标准更强有力的收入贫困衡量标准，并且计算了许多官方衡量标准忽略的收入税收抵免和实物福利等措施显示，2021 年至 2022 年贫困人口大幅增加。正如我所说，这是人们普遍预期的，因为我们知道大流行时期对人们收入的许多政策支持已在 2022 年到期对于儿童来说，到期的主要因素是 2021 年扩大儿童税收抵免。这并不是导致儿童贫困以及 2021 年至 2022 年总体贫困增加的唯一因素，但对于儿童来说，这是一个主要因素

;

;;我们是否知道它占了故事的一部分？;

;

;是的，儿童贫困率为 5.2%到 2021 年，这一数字将增加到 12.4%，到 2022 年，这一数字将增加到 12.4%，翻了一倍多。我们上周发表了一篇文章，其中表明，如果 2022 年扩大的儿童税收抵免仍然有效，儿童贫困率将约为 8.1%，远低于人口普查的 12.4%。对于儿童来说，贫困率仍然会上升。但故事还有其他部分。 2021 年，我们获得了第三轮刺激付款，或所谓的“经济影响付款”。 There was also the continuation of some other expansions to the safety net such as emergency allotments in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (;SNAP;).

;
;
;

;;So, from what we can tell, slightly more than half the increase in child poverty was due to the expiration of the credit.;

;

;Correct.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;Your center wrote a ;report; in the beginning of 2022, looking at just the jump from December, 2021, to January, 2022, after the expiration of the expanded credit, and you found an even bigger increase in child poverty than the recent census report showed. Could this have been even worse?;

;

;I think it's important to understand that the numbers we released in 2022 came from our estimation of monthly poverty rates. So it's a method that we developed to try to understand the poverty rates in the population in advance of the annual statistics that come out each year from the Census Bureau. One important and key difference between the two measures is that our monthly series is really trying to capture the inflow of income in a given month compared with the poverty rate in a given month, whereas an annual poverty measure is aggregating income across the calendar year.

;

;Our monthly series would ask how much the monthly payment in July, for example, reduced the child poverty rate in July, whereas the census numbers that came out last week are asking how all the income pooled across the calendar compared with an annual poverty measure. But, despite the differences, both show that the expiration of the expanded child tax credit threw a lot more children into poverty after keeping a lot of children out of poverty while those payments were in place.

;

;;Can you talk a little bit about how the child tax credit works and why you think it has been so successful?;

;
;
;

;The child tax credit has been around for about twenty-six years and historically has operated as part of people's tax filing and tax refunds. It's been what the IRS calls partially refundable so that, for upper-income families, the credit can reduce the amount of taxes that people owe at tax time. And then, for lower- and more moderate-income families, they can get a partial credit as a refund at tax time. Before the 2021 expansion, the maximum credit that one could be eligible for was two thousand dollars per child. And not everyone got that. The maximum that people could get as a refund, for example, was only fourteen hundred dollars per child.

;

;There's an earnings floor, essentially, before you get anything. And then the credit would phase in as earnings increase. Our research at the center has shown that in the pre-expansion form of the credit, a lot of children were left out or left behind by that credit structure, particularly the children in the lowest-income families. A lot of people got only a partial credit, and some families with children got no credit at all. You needed substantial levels of earnings to get the full credit that was available to middle- and upper-middle-class families.

;
;
;

;In 2021, the American Rescue Plan expanded the credit for that year and basically made three big changes. One change was that it increased the maximum size of the benefit levels, from two thousand to three thousand dollars per child for older children, six and above, and thirty-six hundred dollars per child for younger children, ages zero to five. The second major change is that it made the credit fully refundable and available to all families with children at the lower end of the income distribution and no longer tied to the earnings levels of their parents. The third major change was that the credit was delivered monthly in the last six months of 2021. So half of the credit was delivered to most families in July through December, in the middle of the month, and then the second half of the credit was delivered when families filed their taxes in early 2022. Those are the three major changes. They were in existence only for that year. And, as of 2022, the law reverted to its pre-pandemic form.

;

;;This year, after we found out that the federal expansion was not going to be permanent, a number of states have stepped in and tried to increase their own child tax credits. What do we know about those efforts, and is it too early to see what effect they might be having? How much hope do you have that, if the federal government doesn't step in, some of the uptick in poverty rates that we've seen can be mitigated?;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It's been exciting to see the momentum on this issue at the state level. The federal earned-income tax credit has been around since 1975, but in recent decades a lot of states have adopted a state-level earned-income tax credit. Usually those are pegged as a certain percentage of the federal one, but there really weren't that many state-level child tax credits before the federal expansion. So, like you said, a number of states have pursued or created or expanded state-level child tax credits in the past year or two, and it is a little too soon to look at all their impacts because they're going into effect at different times, and not all of them were fully in effect in 2022, which is the most recent data we have from the Census Bureau.

;

;The other thing I would note about them is that they tend to be much smaller than the 2021 expanded federal credit. They vary a lot in terms of size, and the degree to which they're fully refundable, like the federal expanded credit was. In some states, they're more like rebates. They also vary in terms of whether they're permanent or temporary. But it's exciting to see, and we'll learn a lot more as more states put them into practice. And, of course, states have to balance their budgets every year as opposed to the federal government. So often they have less money to create and institute such a credit.

;

;;Has it been mostly blue states that have tried to put in some sort of expansion recently, or has it been bipartisan? In part because this was a tax credit and not a government program, there was hope that the credit would be a bipartisan thing going forward. Have you seen that on the state level?;

;

;They have tended to be blue states. New York had one before the pandemic and expanded it after the pandemic. The state had a credit that was only for children age five and above, and they extended the eligibility to younger children. California had one and has one still. A lot of the states that have been creating new ones tended to be the bluer states, like Maryland and Minnesota.

;

;;The report says that the biggest increase in child poverty was in the South. Do we know much about regional distinctions? It seems that state-level efforts to fill in for the federal government are less likely to happen there, which would mean less help for the places with the worst child poverty.;

;

;We showed in a report last year that the impacts of the credit on the reduction in poverty in 2021 were largest in the states that had a lower cost of living. The supplemental measure will have a higher poverty line in more expensive places, such as California and Washington, DC Sometimes there's a lower poverty line in places in the South where housing costs are much lower. So the credit, which doesn't vary regionally, is the same amount in Mississippi as it is in California, but essentially can do more anti-poverty impact when the poverty line is lower to begin with. Part of what might be going on is that the Southern states might be losing more in relative terms because of the size of the benefit relative to their poverty line.

;
;
;

;;There's been some talk about further federal expansions, and what we hear from politicians who seem more skeptical than most Democrats is that it would have to be bundled with work requirements. What exactly would a work requirement be, and how would that function in practice?;

;

;So the way the child tax credit works, or worked before the pandemic, and how it works again now is it does have essentially what you would call a work requirement. You receive any amount of dollars from the credit only if you meet this earnings threshold, which is a few thousand dollars. In a sense, you have to work to get anything from it. And, to qualify for the full credit, you have to have pretty substantial earnings. As your earnings rise, you would get a larger credit, and then that plateaus for a while. And then, as your earnings get really quite substantial, the credit would again begin to phase out and become smaller. There are some people whose families have too much earnings to get anything from the credit, but that's a small fraction of families. That's usually what people are talking about when they're talking about instituting a work requirement: preserving that earnings floor and that phase-in with earnings as earnings increase.

;

;But I think it's really important that all children are able to benefit from this program, and that it not be just a middle-class subsidy. We've shown the importance that investments in children's family incomes can have for their long-term well-being and development. Kids who are not in poverty go on to earn more in the labor market, be healthier, all sorts of things that we want as a society. The other point that I often make to people is that incomes aren't a fixed characteristic. So, when you actually take a longer view, a lot more American families with children will experience a period of hard times and a period of low income. Having a robust child tax credit provides a bit of insurance against the risk of hard times.

;

;;And it could even affect non-parental caregivers, such as grandparents, correct?;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Yeah, absolutely. The expanded credit was for all children, except, of course, some of the highest-earning families' children. Whoever was claiming the child on their taxes would be the person receiving that money.

;

;;I don't want to slight the scale of what happened, but when you look at a chart of child poverty in the United States, which obviously is embarrassing, child poverty is still significantly below what it was a decade ago or even a couple decades ago.这是为什么？ And, even if what we saw in 2022 was horrific, what lessons can we learn from the longer-term trend of declining child poverty?;

;

;At Columbia, we actually created a version of the supplemental poverty measure that I described earlier, going all the way back to 1967. It tries to capture in a consistent way the definition of income that includes not just cash income but these in-kind benefits and tax credits and the like. When we look at that over the long term, we do see that poverty has come down pretty dramatically over the past five-plus decades. A lot of that progress has come from policy alone. So that's a success story, but it's also a story that the labor market and all the economic progress and gains that we've had in the past five decades haven't necessarily translated into reductions in poverty unless you count the resources from government policies and programs.

;

;One lesson that we take from the recent expansion is that policy matters a lot, and policy can reduce child poverty and reduce need in this country as long as we have sustained effort behind it. But unfortunately it was just one year where we conducted this experiment in social policy. The second lesson is that unfortunately we still need policy to be doing this work as opposed to our normal labor market and other institutions.

;
;
;

;;When you say that this episode shows that policies work, what specifically with regard to children are we talking about in addition to the child tax credit?;

;Policies tend to work together, but it's not just the child tax credit by any means. So you have the earned-income tax credit, which was expanded periodically since it was created, in 1975. The ;SNAP; program as well has become increasingly important in recent years, especially after cash welfare was largely dismantled in the mid-nineties. There are smaller programs, such as the National School Lunch Program, which provide important support. Social Security and its expansion in the seventies were a huge driver of reduction in elderly poverty. ;The filmmaker David Pisonero Tarantino was asking himself a big question before making his short documentary “Encarnación”: What is the secret to happiness? “I was in a not-so-good place,” he told me, “wondering if I wanted to be a director, how to be a director, how to live off of doing film.” Tarantino was in that impossible place where one's source of joy and purpose and satisfaction clashes with material constraints. What if, he wondered, his artistic goals were not goals at all but, rather, dreams, designed to eventually be discarded?

;

;That's when he turned to his great-aunt Encarnación.

;

;As a nonagenarian, blind, retired schoolteacher, Encarnación was happy. It wasn't a ceaseless euphoria, per se, but she was content, and that in itself was exceptional. It was not the bliss of ignorance—she was bright, always smiling. How was that possible? How could one look at life in such a beautiful way, not just existing to see things through but actually enjoying what life has to offer? How does one become more like Encarnación?

;
;
;
;;;;The New Yorker Documentary;;;

;;View the latest or submit your own film.;

;
;;;;;;
;
;

;The namesake short is the resulting examination. Filmed on Encarnación's ninety-fifth birthday, with great-aunt as interviewee and nephew as interviewer, the documentary attempts, in a literal way, to witness life the way Encarnación does. “She always told me that all she could see was shadows and blurry images,” Tarantino said. “So I wanted to show that.” With the use of a slow shutter speed, Tarantino's vision of his great-aunt is stilted, fuzzy. Her words as she talks to her nephew are then scrawled and scratched across the screen, as if she were writing a letter to us, the curious seekers of contentment. “;Café con leche, y azúcar en el café,;” she quietly chants throughout the short—like a prayer, or, perhaps, like an answer to a prayer—describing a beloved ritual. This isn't an homage to Encarnación; rather, it's an embodiment.

;
;
;

;A fleet of photographs flashes onto the screen, offering rare moments of visual clarity. The picture sharpens, too, when Tarantino meditates on the domestic doodads that Encarnación has accumulated in nearly a hundred years of living: a small bed squeezed between a wall and an armchair, amber from the glow of a lamp; a vase full of pastel fabric flowers; a plaque, dedicated to “Encarnita,” from her former students that reads “;ERES REGAÑONA, PERO NOSOTRAS . 。 。 TE QUEREMOS MUCHO!!;”

;

;Tarantino still doesn't quite know how filmmaking will figure into his life. Encarnación's life suggests a possibility: that the question of professional aspirations could be different from the question of happiness. “I needed to find a way to understand how to enjoy the ride,” he told me. “And I think she explained it perfectly.” For Encarnación, life is about having a sense of play. You are the one who gets to decide whether you're happy or not. That decision may look like taking time for small pleasures—say, savoring a good cup of coffee instead of merely getting caffeinated. ;Café con leche, y azúcar en el café.;

;

;Initially, Tarantino said, “this was a film for myself, to remind myself how to be happier in life, but I'm so happy to see that it became so much more. This way, Encarnación can help another person who's going through a tough time.” He then added, “I know that she will love that.”

;这一切都是在 Walter Isaacson 的 ;马斯克的新传记;。马斯克的家族史与这场争论有关，但是，正如我在书中指出的;在一篇评论;中，艾萨克森只是粗略地讨论了马斯克的祖父 JN Haldeman，他将他描述为一位敢于冒险的冒险家，并认为他的政治观点“古怪”。事实上，霍尔德曼是一位支持种族隔离、反犹太主义的阴谋论者，他将世界上困扰他的大部分问题归咎于犹太金融家。

;

;埃隆·马斯克对他祖父的政治观点不负有责任，他的祖父在去世时就去世了。马斯克当时三岁。但霍尔​​德曼的遗产揭示了社交媒体的作用：大多数人不了解马斯克祖父的政治著作的原因是，在他一生中社交媒体并不存在，因此像他这样的人的著作并没有被放大。它。事实上，它们不太可能广泛流通，现在也相当罕见。尽管如此，它们并不难找到，这使得艾萨克森既没有引用也没有提及它们。

;

;马斯克说过他;购买 Twitter; 以阻止“清醒病毒”在网上传播。他的祖父写了他的小册子，对广播和电视上他所谓的“精神控制”发出警报，“对白人进行无条件的宣传战。”

;

;霍尔德曼出生于1902 年出生于明尼苏达州，但主要在加拿大萨斯喀彻温省长大。作为一名勇敢的飞行员，有时还当过牛仔，他还接受过脊椎按摩师的培训和工作。在十九世纪三十年代，他加入了准法西斯主义;技术官僚运动;，其支持者认为，统治者应该是科学家和工程师，而不是人民。他成为加拿大该运动的领导人，当该运动被短暂取缔时，他被监禁，此后他成为当时臭名昭著的反犹太主义政党“社会信用”的全国主席。十九世纪四十年代，他打着该党的旗号竞选公职，但失败了。 1950 年，南非实行种族隔离两年后，他举家搬到比勒陀利亚，在那里他成为该政权的热情捍卫者。

;

;在互联网时代之前，政治极端分子的著作往往是私人出版，数量相当少。一个愤怒的人写下关于隐形世界政府的备忘录，可能会制作一些油印机或复写本，但最终进入图书馆、编目和保存的可能性很小。据推测，霍尔德曼的大部分文件如果没有被销毁，仍然掌握在家人手中。但他的一些作品幸存下来，包括密歇根州立大学图书馆非凡的 ;激进主义收藏;。

;
;
;

;2017 年，该收藏获得了霍尔德曼的两本小册子，作为来自一位匿名捐赠者的宝藏的一部分，现已发展到一万九千件右翼宣传和阴谋文学。霍尔德曼的其中一本小册子《建立世界独裁政权的国际阴谋和对南非的威胁》的日期为 1960 年 5 月。时机很重要。 1960 年 2 月，英国首相哈罗德·麦克米伦在南非议会发表了著名的“变革之风”演讲，反对种族隔离并敦促接受独立运动：“变革之风正在吹过这片大陆，并且，无论我们喜欢与否，这种民族意识的增长都是一个政治事实。” 3 月，南非警方向沙佩维尔警察局外抗议的数千名南非黑人开枪，造成包括儿童在内的 69 人死亡，近 200 人受伤。电视捕捉到了杀戮过程，并报道到了世界各地。在随后的抗议活动和紧急状态中，;纳尔逊·曼德拉;是被捕并被逮捕的一万八千人之一。被监禁。霍尔德曼的小册子捍卫白人统治，反对反对它的“国际阴谋”。

;有声图片始于 1927 年的音乐剧《爵士歌手》以及拍摄从那时起，音乐表演就成为了艺术的战场。对于伟大的表演者来说，朴素的录音是一种美德。电影在保存舞台上的歌舞方面发挥着档案作用，否则这些歌舞就会消失在历史之中。但电影本身就是一门艺术，当表演在没有审美的情况下拍摄时，结果就会令人麻木，正如早期音乐剧电影的起起伏伏所反映的那样。在《爵士歌手》取得成功之后，这种类型被过度使用和忽视，很快就成为票房毒药，直到巴斯比·伯克利在《;42 街;”（1933 年）。这种冲突持续存在，尤其是在音乐会电影这一子类型中，导演对动作和摄像机位置的控制有限，因此很难制作出时尚的电影作品。已故的;乔纳森·戴米; — 1984 年拍摄的电影《Stop Making Sense》，讲述了 Talking Heads 乐队的表演。 （现在正在院线重新上映，并进行了新的修复。）

;

;戴米 - 无论是在他之前的电影中，例如“公民乐队”和“梅尔文和霍华德”，还是他后来的更著名的电影，包括《沉默的羔羊》、《费城》和《瑞秋结婚》——擅长追踪演员阵容的复杂互动。同样的艺术冲动也是《Stop Making Sense》的核心，它将 1983 年 12 月在好莱坞潘特吉斯剧院举行的三场 Talking Heads 表演的部分内容拼接在一起，以唤起一场音乐会的效果。凭借戴米的戏剧性特征，乐团的创作是他以演员为中心的导演道德的产物，但在《Stop Making Sense》中，他通过创造独特的形象剧目来实现这种感觉，强调乐队成员的相互作用并提供清晰的视觉效果音乐会开始时，乐队主唱大卫·伯恩 (David Byrne) 独自站在舞台上，穿着浅色西装和白色运动鞋，弹着原声吉他，唱着“Psycho Killer”旁边的音箱里传来预先录制的节拍。他并不孤单（在他身后可以看到工作人员），但是，他凭借自己的智慧和专注表演，看起来就像是从拼图中掉下来的一块。这是一场富有意义的表演，凸显了他孤独的不足，而电影只有在下一首歌曲《天堂》中才爆发出生命力，乐队的贝斯手蒂娜·韦茅斯也加入了他的行列。戴米将两位音乐家放在一起：伯恩在前景中表情丰富，而韦茅斯在背景中，穿着连身裤，在伯恩演奏时注视着她。

;

;与此同时，工作人员推着一个立管和一个乐队的另外两位创始成员走上舞台，准备下一集：吉他手兼键盘手杰里·哈里森 (Jerry Harrison) 非常专业，但鼓手克里斯·弗朗茨 (Chris Frantz) 穿着 Polo 衫，他的“哎呀”咧嘴一笑，看起来就像高中高尔夫球队的成员，因被邀请与艺术孩子们一起即兴演奏而感到高兴和惊讶。戴米的取景根据配置进行调整，从音乐家身后对角拍摄，以便屏幕充满他们重叠且对比鲜明的节奏动作——与“谢谢你送我一个天使”的奔腾和“找到工作”的节奏形成视觉对立”。最后，乐队新招募的五名新成员浮出水面：键盘手 Bernie Worrell（P-Funk 的联合创始人）、主唱 Lynn Mabry（同样来自 P-Funk）和 Ednah Holt、吉他手 Alex Weir 和打击乐手 Steve秤。这五位音乐家都是黑人，他们的声音主要植根于放克，而 Talking Heads 的四位创始成员是白人，在这种融合中，乐队宣布风格的相遇和融合作为其音乐和智力项目的核心。作为一名九位成员，Talking Heads 成为一个热情而欢快的团体，其音乐和表现力范围得到了扩展，而 Demme 也扩展了他的电影词汇来与之匹配。

;

;Talking Heads 和其他音乐家出现在这个时代是有原因的。十九世纪七十年代——金发女郎、埃尔维斯·科斯特洛、电视、B-52 乐队和雷蒙斯乐队——被称为新浪潮。这个词不仅仅是代际标记。就像法国新浪潮电影制作人一样，这些摇滚乐手对他们的艺术有着历史的视角，并将其融入到他们的音乐中。在摇滚乐从声名狼藉的边缘走向稳固的主流的过程中成长起来，他们继承了一种流派，这种流派的新地位使他们有勇气在丰富的内心音乐百科全书的基础上创作大胆前瞻的音乐。

;
;< /div>;

;《Talking Heads》在其方法上从根本上是参考性的，引用了摇滚和流行的风格和基调，而不是完全属于其中任何一种。例如，伯恩捕捉并美化了罗伊·奥比森音乐中本质上的孤独感。奥比森音乐的孤独植根（或无根）于广阔的空间，而伯恩的音乐则是一种充实的孤独，一种在不可避免的城市人群和复杂技术的疏远影响中的孤立。 《Stop Making Sense》在富有表现力的特写镜头中捕捉到了伯恩将他的技术异化带入生活的自觉机械的笨拙。在“Once in a Lifetime”中，他开始重复自己，然后敲头打破循环，就好像他是一个有缺陷的机器人。

;

;乐队在“Stop Making Sense”中的扩展阵容同样是自我-意识到的。在集体想象中，组建乐队是郊区白人中产阶级内心孤独的一种救赎。从艺术角度来说，阵容中五位黑人放克音乐家的到来与;让-吕克·戈达尔;选角美国女演员;Jean Seberg; 在《气喘吁吁》中。 《Talking Heads》制作出真正的惊悚片的可能性并不比戈达尔制作好莱坞黑色电影的可能性大，但他们所做的不仅仅是向他们的影响和灵感的遥不可及的理想致敬；他们创作的艺术记录了这些影响的变革力量。一旦五重奏加入，乐队就变成了一台强大的机器，戴米用全景、正面的图像来美化它，捕捉充满舞台的能量。不断扩大的摄像机角度阵列捕捉到了各个音乐家之间引发的几乎突触的联系。伯恩与马布里和霍尔特的互动将他的戏剧想象力推向了一个新的疯狂水平。当他们开玩笑地模仿他在“战时生活”中原地奔跑时的滑稽动作后，他加大了赌注，开始在舞台上以巨大的椭圆形奔跑。在《Crossseyed and Painless》中，他在歌手的合唱连复段中对声感叹，将言语智慧与手势发明的讽刺手法结合在一起。他从夸张的尴尬中提取出的悲情和幽默总是与强度相平衡。事实上，他戏剧性的孤独似乎是雅克·塔蒂式的——他在《This Must Be the Place》中与棒灯跳舞甚至可以是“;播放时间;”参考。 （;超大四角西装< /a>; 伯恩在电影中几场比赛中所穿的衣服已经成为标志性的，但它也是多余的：他已经在整场音乐会的表演中表达了其本质。）戴米将孤独的伯恩和嗡嗡作响的乐队并置是表现主义的：伯恩，紧紧地照亮在《一生一次》中，从侧面看，他看起来着魔了，就像一个狂躁的传教士；当艾尔·格林 (Al Green) 的《带我去河边》中的福音情色将整个乐队带入欣喜若狂的能量顶峰时，电影摄影似乎也加入了进来，呈现出令人兴奋的一系列鲜明对比的角度和充满活力的平移镜头。

;<戴米在《Stop Making Sense》中唤起的戏剧性是表演合作中产生的艺术自我超越。这个想法的时机已经到来，并且几乎同时被另外两位电影制作人探索：戈达尔和 ;尚塔尔·阿克曼;。戈达尔的《名字：卡门》是这部歌剧的更新版黑色电影，其中比才的大部分音乐被贝多芬的弦乐四重奏所取代，在银幕上表演并以大胆的、绘画般的视觉对位感拍摄。阿克曼的纪录片“;皮娜询问的一天”。 。 .;”，描绘了 ;Pina Bausch; 和她的公司伍珀塔尔舞蹈剧院 (Tanztheater Wuppertal)在行动中，对表演者之间的重叠和交叉表现出类似的关注。对于更加和蔼可亲、在艺术上更加节制的戴米来说，戈达尔和阿克曼的陪伴似乎有些奇怪——但是，在《别再胡思乱想》中，他在自己的艺术创作上达到了大胆的极限。这部电影不仅见证了灵感合作的超越自我的力量，而且作为一部艺术作品，它也体现了这一点。 ♦

;问答进行到一半。 ;妮基·黑利;市政厅的一部分本月早些时候，在新罕布什尔州梅里马克的对外战争退伍军人哨所，一位名叫特德·约翰逊的男子站起来宣布美国正在走向内战。 “那么，”他问海莉，“我怎样才能回到十九世纪八十年代的那一天，那时我很快乐，在街上跑步，骑自行车？”

;

;碰巧，海莉经常提起八十年代。她最近出版的书的标题取自玛格丽特·撒切尔夫人的名言，她在竞选活动中经常引用撒切尔夫人的话。上个月，在第一届共和党总统辩论上在这场辩论;中，她向迄今为止最多的观众抛出了“如果你想要做某事，就去问女人”这句台词。 2 月份，黑莉竞选活动的一段视频预告片以珍妮·柯克帕特里克 (Jeane Kirkpatrick)（民主党人后来成为罗纳德·里根 (Ronald Reagan) 的新保守主义外交政策顾问）在 1984 年共和党全国代表大会上发表讲话的一段模糊片段开始。

;

;美国总统竞选季节非常漫长，大多数候选人通常都有机会享受“片刻”。这是尼基·黑利的：CNN 最近的大选预选赛预选赛显示，她以最大优势击败了;乔·拜登;共和党候选人，包括;唐纳德·特朗普;。 After the first debate, which, as the Washington ;Post; ;put it;, Haley “won on brains and experience,” David Brooks ;wrote; that it was time to “give Haley her chance”; even ;The New Republic; had a ;piece; about why she “scares the Biden campaign.” Haley doesn't present as an isolationist or a populist; she doesn't call the government “the regime” or compare the country to the Roman Empire in decline; at her events that I attended, she never said the word “woke,” or even “liberal” or “élites.” She favors the cliché “I've always spoken in hard truths,” a simple bromide that manages to distinguish her in the non-Trump GOP primary lineup—not haranguing like ;Ron DeSantis; or ;Vivek Ramaswamy;, not as lifeless as ;Mike Pence;'s comparable appeal to the golden age.

;

;At the Veterans of Foreign Wars post, a flashing sign at the entrance advertised a meat raffle. A former Air Force nurse had introduced Haley, who paced in flared bluejeans and a white lace sweater. When Johnson asked her how he could get back to the eighties, she took his disillusionment and wistfulness for a bygone era as an opening for a poignant yarn—the kind of story that Democrats usually tell—about a daughter of immigrants burying the Confederate flag.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;“I don't know if y'all remember, we had a horrific church shooting in South Carolina a few years ago,” she said. She recounted how, in 2015, a young white man had murdered nine Black churchgoers at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, in Charleston, after participating in a Bible study with them. The shooter's writings called for a race war, and his Web site included photos of him with the Confederate flag; Haley decided it was time for South Carolina to take down that flag from in front of the statehouse, where it had flown since 1961. To persuade state lawmakers to vote in favor, Haley said, she told them about accompanying her father, a Sikh who taught at a historically Black college, to buy groceries on an excursion from the small town where they lived; the shopkeepers called the police when they saw her father's turban. “Every time I have to go to the airport, I have to pass that produce stand. And, every time I pass it, I feel pain. Don't make any child have to pass the statehouse and see that flag and feel pain.”

;

;After the town hall, I sat in a folding chair next to Johnson. “I was for Trump in 2016 and 2020, but now I want unity,” he told me. “I'm a Haley convert. I ordered her sign last night. Right now, I have one up for Burgum, but that's coming down.” I told him that I thought I saw him tearing up during Haley's riff about the flag. “I had totally forgot about that,” he said. “She was the one who actually got it taken down—she worked with Republicans, Democrats, faith leaders, community leaders. When I say the nineteen-eighties, Mom let me out of the house and I didn't come home until dark. Everybody liked each other, everybody was happy. Me and my wife are Independents now, and Haley's going to pull in people like us. She's going to pull moderate Democrats, too.” He went on, “You got a lot of that Trump base right here, in the backwoods. They want Hunter to pay, they want Hillary to pay. That ain't moving our country nowhere.”

;
;
;

;“Do you remember, when you were growing up, how simple life was, how safe it felt?” Haley had asked the crowd, which applauded as she walked off to “American Girl,” by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. “Don't you want that again?” They did, and they do. Haley said that she raised a million dollars within seventy-two hours of the first debate, and her campaign swing through New Hampshire had a triumphant tone. During her town halls, I noticed audience members using her phrasing unprompted. (“I'm here because of the debate,” one voter said, “and you told hard truths.”) Melinda Tourangeau, a Desert Storm veteran in pearls, pink lipstick, and a striped blazer, told me, “I haven't loved a politician this much since Ronald Reagan.”

;

;Haley's pitch for the future harks back to a more traditional vision of the GOP—the type of candidacy one might think the contemporary Party would have no use for—but a canny establishment conservative may be Biden's greatest threat. Haley is now tied with DeSantis for second place in the New Hampshire primary polls—Trump, of course, is first—but, more significant, she seems to hold real appeal for a swath of moderate suburban voters whom Biden needs to win. She took down the Confederate flag, isn't forthrightly hostile to transgender rights or a woman's right to choose, and sides with liberal internationalism in her support for ;Ukraine;. She's the first female minority governor in the country, and she's never lost an election. Her pitch is notably inclusive: “We should want to win the majority of Americans,” she said. “Our solutions are the right ones, but you don't do it by pushing people away. You do it by opening the tent. We need more people in. We need young people, we need women, we need African Americans, we need Asians, we need Hispanics. And you don't go to them and say, 'You should be with us.' You go to them and say, 'What do you care about?' ”

;

;The day before the VFW, Haley had been in Claremont, a formerly prosperous mill town by the Vermont border, for a town hall in the game room of a local senior center. A license plate pinned to the wall read “Retired: No Worry, No Hurry, No Phone, No Boss.” Nearby was a sign warning people not to fall for scams; dinner, according to a menu written in cursive on a whiteboard, would be shepherd's pie. Haley walked in wearing a blue striped blouse and white, open-toe espadrilles that showed a light-pink pedicure. The event was small; there weren't more than ten attendees per reporter.

;

;Haley usually opens her stump speech with an abbreviated family origin story: the only Indians in a two-stoplight South Carolina town—“We weren't white enough to be white, we weren't Black enough to be Black”—where her parents told her how blessed they were to be in America. She talks about dropping off her husband, a combat veteran, at four in the morning for a yearlong deployment to Africa. She points out that, before politics, she was an accountant who graduated from a public university. (No law school, no Ivy League.) She always says, “The first thing we're going to have to tackle is this national self-loathing that has taken over our country”—a callback to Kirkpatrick's “Blame America first” speech, in which she said that the American people understand “the dangers of endless self-criticism and self-denigration.” Haley likes to conclude by insisting that she's glad to have been underestimated for her entire life: “It makes me scrappy.”

;
;
;

;She also musters bits of jovial, canned banter without inducing the cringe of Pence or DeSantis, or, for that matter, the current President. She makes an attentive, active-listening face, smiles, and doesn't interrupt; she stopped mid-sentence to say “Bless you” to someone who sneezed in the back of the room. She held a voter's crying baby and stayed late to talk to the local cops manning the event. Two women next to me debriefed: “That was great—someone who actually accomplished something.” Two school-age kids wanted Haley's autograph, and, when they got to the front of the line, she knelt down to confer with them at length before signing “God bless you” into their notebooks.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;
;
;
;

;GOP events in New Hampshire aren't just attended by Republicans looking for a post-Trump candidate; many of the audience members were Democrats and Independents listening closely to see if they could find an alternative to Biden. At the town hall in Claremont, I talked to Barre Pinske, who wore turquoise, horn-rimmed glasses. “I'm an artist, a sculptor, so I should be a Democrat,” he said. “I like Obama and Reagan. Obama was cool, he could ride around with Jerry Seinfeld, and Reagan was a man's man. I'm not married and I don't have kids, but I have family values. All that sort of stuff matters to me. So just because I'm a free spirit, I still have a nostalgic, American kind of perspective.” He went on, “The Republican Party is messed up, and, if someone doesn't come in as more centrist, the Republicans have no chance to win. I would like to see them get somebody who can get those swing voters. I'm the kind of voter they're looking for, and I'm drinking the Haley Kool-Aid.”

;

;Haley is the only female candidate in the GOP primary, a fact that many voters in New Hampshire told me, unbidden, they were drawn to. When Haley declared her candidacy, back in February, Don Lemon was benched from CNN for saying that, at fifty-one, she was “past her prime.” (Afterward, Haley said that she raised twenty-five thousand dollars for her campaign by selling beer koozies that read “;PAST MY PRIME;?”) Pinske told me, “She brings a maternal spirit to a leadership position.” Haley mostly comes across as hawkish and tough, but she does occasionally embrace a certain maternal energy. Of South Carolina, post-shooting, she said, “I had to put my arms around my state and protect her.” Later: “I think we need a mom in the White House.”

;

;At the Vets post in Merrimack, her hawkishness had the crowd cheering. A man named Paul in an American-flag T-shirt told me, “I want somebody willing to pull the nuclear trigger with China. Get it over with, even if it would be the end of us. Margaret Thatcher, Golda Meir—we need somebody tough.” Haley's international experience appeals: a former Army nurse named Barbara Healey said, “We could have Russia, China, North Korea banging on our door—we need someone who can deal with that.” The audience loves when Haley says that being the UN Ambassador allowed her to take the “Kick Me” sign off America's back. I wondered how her interventionist policy in Ukraine would play, given that Trump, DeSantis, and Ramaswamy all want less US involvement. She pitched giving weapons and money to Ukraine as a short-term patriotic duty; a quick end to the war would keep veterans like her husband from going to fight, and be a display of strength to China and Russia.

;

;When asked about post-Roe America, Haley responds with a display of equivocation that avoids alienating most pro-life voters while also managing to bring in liberals. “I'm going to tell you my hard truth, because I don't think Americans get the truth on this situation,” she said, in Merrimack. “I don't judge anyone who's pro-choice.” She mentioned a college roommate who was raped; she talks about her husband's adoption and her own difficulty conceiving. Haley's appeals to consensus—“Can't we all agree?”—save her from the extremes that would lose her votes, but also reveal to some a crucial lack of conviction on issues that should define her. “The paradox is that she says all of this stuff, but she'll still campaign and vote for Trump when it comes to it,” Stuart Stevens, a former Republican political consultant, told me. “This is somebody who has courted and said positive things about the most right-wing elements of the Party. The differences between Haley and Marjorie Taylor Greene are ultimately purely aesthetic, but I don't think MTG is reading polls to remind her of her deeply felt beliefs. There's a frivolousness to Haley running for President and trying to please everybody.” Haley frames this differently, as a “story of addition.” Shortly after announcing her candidacy, she told Bari Weiss, “There's a reason that I'm more likely to win a general election than anyone else. It's because I identify with ;so; many different people.”

;
;
;

;After the Vets post, Haley visited the Founders Academy, a charter school in Manchester, to do a town hall with Tiffany Justice, a founder of the conservative advocacy group ;Moms for Liberty;. Beforehand, she sat at a roundtable with the school principal, some teachers, and a couple of moms running for the local school board. In the sweltering classroom, a poster with an inspirational quote—“Life Is Tough, My Darling, but So Are You”—hung next to the works of Shakespeare arranged by color. One of the moms at the table fanned her baby with a pocket Constitution. Haley kept it boring. “We don't want Democrat and Republican parents,” she said. “We want all parents. Don't all parents want transparency?” During the town hall, held in the school library, a press photographer sitting on a shelf crashed through it, sending colored pencils flying everywhere. Haley told a story about how, when she was in seventh grade, her dad didn't sign her sex-ed permission slip, so she had to sit in a room alone during the course. “That's not for the schools to decide,” she said.

;

;Haley said that Biden had called her out as a “;MAGA; extremist” for doing an event with Moms for Liberty. “Then count me as one of them!” she joked. She presented as traditional, not extreme, making all the points that conservatives want to hear without devolving into a full-time battle with Disney or promising to abolish the Department of Education, in the bellicose vein of DeSantis and Ramaswamy. She managed the same thing with transgender questions as she did with abortion, at times coming across as almost progressive compared with most other GOP candidates. “I believe in freedom,” Haley said. “If an adult decides that they want to transition, they are welcome to do that.” (Recently, even Trump seems to sense danger in taking uncompromising positions on these matters: he called DeSantis's abortion ban a “terrible mistake” and told Megyn Kelly that he'd heard a man can now give birth.) At the senior center, Haley had reminded the crowd that Republicans have lost the popular vote in seven of the past eight Presidential elections, and that seventy-eight per cent of parents don't think their children will have a better life than they did. By acquitting herself with Moms for Liberty while toeing a moderate line, her subtle rebuttal of Biden was the idea that this all ;could; be simple again, not a forever war between progressives and extremists. Haley shared an anecdote that she often rolls out on the campaign trail, recalling her mother's advice to her when she was teased in school for being Indian: “Your job isn't to show them how you're different. Your job is to show them how you're similar.”

;

;In Claremont, during a Q. & A., a voter named Dale Giles mistook Haley for Tulsi Gabbard. After Haley clarified that she wasn't, Giles still launched into his critique: “It seems like you have an axe to grind with Trump. I've got nothing but the utmost respect for you.” Giles wore a Dodge hat and a shirt styled to resemble the Walmart label that read “Biden: Pay More. Live Worse”; his cell phone was ringing loudly in his pocket. He had more of a comment than a question, concluding by suggesting that Haley pick South Dakota's governor, Kristi Noem, as her running mate. (“I think that means you're a fan of women!” Haley responded.) Afterward, Giles went up to take a photo with Haley, and they spoke for several minutes. I asked for his impression of the candidate who minutes ago he thought was somebody else. “I'd love to see Joe take her behind the barn,” he said, smiling and pausing for effect as I waited to see where he was going with it. “And let her kick his ass.”

;

;Even if Haley has the best chance against Biden, it doesn't mean that she'll be the Republican nominee. (In New Hampshire, being tied for second with DeSantis still means that they're both losing to Trump by thirty-seven points.) To the base “in the backwoods,” as Johnson, the eighties nostalgist, calls the ;MAGA; hard-liners, Haley is the archetypal striving representative of the globalist, anti-populist, corporate wing of the Party. In a ;Times; ;roundtable; called “Nikki Haley Will Not Be the Next President,” Daniel McCarthy, the conservative columnist, wrote that she is “too representative of the party elite's desires to be seen as a plausible tribune of the working class.” (At the debate, Ramaswamy wished Haley well in her “future career on the boards of Lockheed and Raytheon.”) She's clearly sensitive to this flaw in her image as a candidate; on a podcast, asked to name the last book she had read, she offered “;Hillbilly Elegy;,” by JD Vance. “Nikki is running for an endowed chair at the Atlantic Council, not a Presidential nomination,” Tucker Carlson told me. “She's not trying to win Trump voters. She's doing something stealthier and more difficult, which is to make professional-class Trump haters forget that, just a few years ago, she worked for him. How many other Trump Cabinet secretaries would the average NPR listener conceivably vote for? Nikki's the only one.”

;

;Haley is gently pitching herself as the one to move the Party beyond Trump—“We have to elect a ;new; conservative leader”—without denouncing him too much, but, in Claremont, she was dogged by demands to articulate her allegiance to the former President. “People are wondering if you were lying when you raised your hand at the debate to say you would support President Trump even if he was in jail,” Giles said. “Can you raise your hand with us now to say that you would support President Trump?” Haley is nimble at pivoting when it comes to what may be the most consequential stance in this race, for those who actually want to win—the precarious Trump line. She reminded voters that she was able to leave the Trump Administration “without a tweet,” dignity intact. Great as the eighties may have been, Haley's pragmatic equivocation might be her best weapon; she understands the “hard truth” of the one real deciding factor about whether a moment can last. Her way out of the yes or no, hand up or down for Trump? “I speak hard truths,” she replied, smiling. ♦

;美国汽车工人联合会罢工现已进入第二个日历周，并且密歇根州和其他地方的共和党人正在上演一场荒谬的政治游戏。经过多年代表大企业的利益并抵制工会支持的立法后，他们声称自己是一个关心罢工汽车工人利益的政党。

;

;正如您所预料的，;唐纳德·特朗普;正在领衔这场表演。上周末，他告诉 NBC 新闻，“汽车工人被他们的领导层出卖了，他们的领导层应该支持特朗普。”他和其他共和党人抓住了这样一个论点，即拜登政府推动电动汽车 (EV) 是对该国汽车工人的背叛，他们大多数在制造汽油车或其零部件的工厂工作。

;

;最后一周，我;写了; UAW 争端给拜登带来了棘手的政治挑战，拜登必须处理其具有里程碑意义的绿色能源政策与对有组织劳工的同情之间的紧张关系。周五在白宫，拜登为罢工的汽车工人辩护，并呼吁汽车制造商确保“创纪录的企业利润意味着美国汽车工人联合会创纪录的合同”。白宫还宣布将派遣拜登高级顾问吉恩·斯珀林(Gene Sperling)，代理劳工部长朱莉·苏 (Julie Su) 前往底特律。

;

;与此同时，特朗普和共和党人看到了推翻密歇根州的机会，这位前总统在 2016 年以微弱优势赢得了密歇根州。他们也着眼于四届民主党议员黛比·斯塔贝诺 (Debbie Stabenow) 将于 2025 年 1 月腾出美国参议院席位。 Politico ;报道;，全国共和党参议院委员会发表声明，声称竞选接替斯塔贝诺的民主党女议员埃丽莎·斯洛特金“通过投票禁止汽油汽车，选择了她的政党而不是密歇根州。 ” （该声明提到斯洛特金上周投票反对众议院共和党法案，该法案将阻止各州限制汽油动力汽车销售的努力。）甚至连著名工人阶级论坛的前副总统迈克·彭斯（Mike Pence）也发表了看法。民主党在去年的《通货膨胀削减法案》中为购买电动汽车提供了巨额补贴。彭斯对 CNN 表示：“利用纳税人的钱推动我们的汽车经济转向电动汽车，这会给 UAW 成员带来极大的焦虑，这是可以理解的。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;政治就是政治，但共和党资深人士冒充工会工人的真正朋友的景象实在是太奇怪了，几乎是滑稽的。自特朗普以来，共和党几十年来一直站在雇主一边，并试图挫败工会组织工作场所和提高工资的努力。尽管共和党试图将自己重新定位为工人政党，但它的行动却嘲笑了这一主张。

;
;
;

;从特朗普开始。 2017年掌权后，他恢复了共和党在五人国家劳工关系委员会中的多数席位，该机构是在新政期间成立的，旨在支持工人组织和集体谈判的权利。特朗普任命前众议院共和党工作人员马文·卡普兰 (Marvin Kaplan) 为国家劳工关系委员会 (NLRB) 主席。在共和党的领导下，该机构迅速采取行动，推翻了奥巴马政府期间发布的几项支持劳工的裁决，其中包括一项让工人快速获得便利的裁决。 - 组织食品特许经营。这种支持雇主的倾向在特朗普整个任期内持续存在。 2019 年 12 月，该机构发布了两项裁决，对工会投票引入了新的限制，并使公司更容易将工人归类为独立承包商，从而剥夺了他们的工会工资标准和福利。

;

;对比这一记录拜登领导下的国家劳工关系委员会采取了行动，拜登任命两名前工会律师为董事会成员，另一名前工会律师詹妮弗·阿布鲁佐 (Jennifer Abruzzo) 担任总法律顾问。在过去几年中，该机构废除了特朗普时代的许多裁决，包括与投票程序和独立承包商有关的裁决。上个月，国家劳工委员会裁定，如果一家公司在工会选举期间有恐吓行为，例如解雇工会组织者，该机构将命令该公司承认工会并进行集体谈判。在另一项裁决中，国家劳工委员会制定了工会投票的新规则，要求及时举行投票，并限制雇主拖延投票的行为，这种情况很常见。

;

;同情工会的劳工活动家和评论员赞扬这些决定。为《美国前景》撰稿，Harold Meyerson ;称赞国家劳工关系委员会的反恐吓法令是“几十年来最重要的裁决”。迈耶森补充道，这两项裁决的共同发布“有效地使工会组织再次成为可能，几十年来，雇主的非法行为不受惩罚，是导致国家私营部门工会化率从大约 35% 降至仅 6% 的最决定性因素”随着工会化率稳步下降，大多数共和党人一直反对扭转这一趋势的立法努力，其中包括两项将使工会更容易组织起来的法案：民主党控制的众议院于 2007 年通过了《雇员自由选择法案》，众议院于 2019 年和 2021 年再次通过了《保护组织权 (;PRO;) 法案》。（后一种情况） ，五位共和党人投票支持该法案；两百零五位没有投票。）

;

;XVERSE (;Borowitz 报告;）——X（以前称为 Twitter）的社交媒体平台的用户即将推出一项计划，要求埃隆·马斯克每月向他们支付费用才能继续使用该网站。

;

;策划该计划的用户 Tracy Klugian 表示，每月 10.99 美元的费用将补偿用户在 X 上的不良体验。

;
;
;

;此外，Klugian 表示，X 用户将要求马斯克拨出数十亿美元，以补偿他们因接触该平台而产生的任何精神科或其他医疗费用。

;

;该提案引起了广泛关注。大量机器人的严厉回应，他们认为马斯克还必须补偿他们继续出现在网站上。

;

;“任何向 X 用户支付月费但不向机器人支付费用的计划都是非常有害的， ”@TrumpBoebert2024 写道。 “机器人让 X 成为今天的样子。”
